theme_1_effectiveness.summary: AI demonstrates significant positive effects on learning outcomes across educational levels
key_findings: Overall AI integration effect: g = 0.86 (large effect)
ITS effectiveness: d ≈ 0.80 (equivalent to human tutoring)
Chatbots/GenAI: g = 1.02 (highest effect)
Adaptive learning: g = 0.45 (medium effect)
STEM subjects show strongest gains

theme_2_genai_impact.summary: Generative AI adoption has exploded, creating both opportunities and challenges
key_findings: Student AI usage: 66% (2024) → 92% (2025)
AI for assessments: 53% (2024) → 88% (2025)
Impact Paradox: High convenience vs. critical thinking concerns
97% faculty see benefits; 90% concerned about critical thinking
Shift toward continuous authentic assessment

theme_3_learning_analytics.summary: AI-powered analytics achieve high accuracy in identifying at-risk students
key_findings: Prediction accuracy: 85-95% in first weeks of semester
XGBoost/Random Forest models most effective
Direct correlation with improved retention rates
Need for socio-emotional data integration

theme_4_ethics_equity.summary: Significant ethical challenges require urgent attention
key_findings: Algorithmic bias against Black/Hispanic students in predictive models
FERPA does not fully cover AI-generated data
European AI Act classifies educational AI as 'high-risk'
Data ownership often resides with EdTech providers
Equity gap risk if AI access is unequal

theme_5_cognitive_impact.summary: AI tools can both enhance and potentially hinder cognitive development
key_findings: 30% increase in student engagement with AI tutors
20% improvement in STEM academic performance
Risk of 'brain disengagement' if AI handles core cognitive tasks
Critical thinking requires intentional pedagogical design
